definitions: take food drink or another substance into the body by swallowing or absorbing
take in and understand information or ideas mentally through reading listening or studying
examples: The patient must ingest these pills with water after meals
Young children often ingest small objects by accident causing concern
Students need time to ingest complex theories before the exam
She could ingest entire books in a single afternoon

definitions: live in or occupy a place or environment as a resident or natural occupant
examples: Various wildlife species inhabit the forest near our cabin
Ancient civilizations used to inhabit these coastal regions

definitions: breathe in air or other substances through the nose or mouth into the lungs
examples: The doctor asked me to inhale deeply during the examination
Don't inhale the smoke from the burning plastic

definitions: hinder restrain or prevent an action process or function from happening or developing
make someone unable to act naturally because of nervousness or self-consciousness
examples: Certain medications can inhibit the growth of cancer cells
Cold temperatures inhibit the chemical reaction from occurring properly
His shyness tends to inhibit him at social gatherings
Don't let fear inhibit you from pursuing your dreams

definitions: set something to its starting position or value especially in computing or technical systems
examples: You need to initialize the variables before running the program
The technician will initialize the system after the software update

definitions: force a liquid medicine or other substance into the body using a syringe or similar device
introduce a new element quality or factor into a situation conversation or process
examples: The nurse will inject the vaccine into your upper arm
The mechanic needs to inject oil into the engine components
She tried to inject some humor into the tense meeting
The company wants to inject fresh ideas into their marketing

definitions: mark write or draw on something using ink from a pen or similar tool
sign a contract or agreement formally making it official and legally binding
examples: The artist will ink the outline after finishing the pencil sketch
Please ink your initials at the bottom of each page
They plan to ink the deal by the end of this week
The athlete finally inked a contract with the professional team

definitions: set pieces of material into a surface to form a decorative pattern or design
examples: The craftsman will inlay mother-of-pearl into the wooden jewelry box
They decided to inlay marble tiles in the bathroom floor

definitions: make changes or introduce new methods ideas or products to improve something significantly
examples: Successful companies must constantly innovate to stay competitive
The chef loves to innovate with traditional recipes

definitions: ask for information from someone or investigate to find out about something
examples: I need to inquire about the status of my application
Several customers called to inquire about our holiday hours

definitions: place fix or insert something inside something else especially as a decorative feature
examples: The jeweler will inset diamonds into the gold ring
They plan to inset a small window in the bathroom door

definitions: look at something or someone carefully to check its quality condition or discover information
examples: The mechanic will inspect your car before issuing the certificate
Health officials regularly inspect restaurants for safety violations

definitions: bring about or initiate an action or event especially something harmful or unpleasant
encourage urge or incite someone to do something especially something wrong
examples: The rumors served to instigate panic among the investors
Political tensions could instigate conflict between the neighboring countries
Don't instigate fights between your siblings
The coach tried to instigate a more aggressive playing style

definitions: gradually but firmly establish an idea feeling or quality in a person's mind
examples: Good teachers instill confidence in their students
Parents try to instill good values in their children

definitions: protect something from heat cold electricity or sound by surrounding it with special material
examples: We need to insulate the attic before winter arrives
Thick curtains help insulate the room from street noise

definitions: speak to or treat someone with disrespect or scornful abuse hurting their feelings
examples: He didn't mean to insult her with his careless comment
The comedian tends to insult audience members during his shows

definitions: arrange for compensation in case of damage loss illness or death by paying premiums
make certain that something will occur or be the case by taking necessary measures
examples: You should insure your new car against theft and accidents
The company will insure the shipment for its full value
Double-check the locks to insure the house is secure
Regular maintenance will insure your equipment lasts longer

definitions: become or make something become stronger more extreme or more concentrated in force or degree
examples: The storm will intensify as it moves over warm water
The coach asked players to intensify their training efforts

definitions: place a dead body in a grave or tomb typically with funeral rites
examples: They will inter his remains in the family cemetery plot
The ancient pharaohs were interred with their treasured possessions

definitions: intervene on behalf of another person especially to settle a dispute or obtain favor
examples: The teacher had to intercede when the students started arguing
She asked her manager to intercede with upper management

definitions: stop catch or seize something or someone that is moving from one place to another
examples: The defender managed to intercept the pass during the game
Security agents will intercept any suspicious packages at the airport

definitions: exchange things or ideas with another person giving one thing and receiving another
cause two or more things to change places or alternate in position or function
examples: The two professors often interchange ideas about their research
You can interchange these parts if one stops working properly
The dancers will interchange positions throughout the performance
The team members interchange roles to learn different skills

definitions: connect two or more things with each other so they can work or communicate together
examples: The new system will interconnect all our regional offices
These underground tunnels interconnect the buildings on campus

definitions: prohibit or forbid something authoritatively especially by legal or ecclesiastical order
examples: The court will interdict the sale of the disputed property
The government moved to interdict illegal arms shipments

definitions: cross or weave things together by passing over and under each other alternately
examples: The artist will interlace gold threads through the fabric design
She likes to interlace her fingers when thinking deeply

definitions: fit or join things together tightly so they cannot be separated easily
examples: The puzzle pieces interlock to create a complete picture
These safety devices interlock to prevent equipment malfunction

definitions: provide or occur as an intervening period of time between events or activities
examples: A musical piece will interlude between the play's two acts
Brief comedy sketches interlude the more serious performances

definitions: act as a mediator or go-between in negotiations or disputes between parties
examples: The diplomat will intermediate between the two warring nations
She often has to intermediate when her children disagree

definitions: work as a trainee or apprentice to gain practical experience in an occupation
confine someone as a prisoner especially for political or military reasons during wartime
examples: She will intern at the law firm during summer break
Medical students must intern at hospitals before graduating
The government decided to intern suspected spies during the war
They were interned in camps far from their homes

definitions: ask questions of someone closely aggressively or formally especially to obtain information
examples: The police will interrogate the suspect about the robbery
The committee plans to interrogate witnesses during the hearing

definitions: meet and cross at a point forming an angle or creating a junction
examples: These two roads intersect at the town center
The hiking trails intersect near the mountain summit

definitions: twist or twine together closely so they become difficult to separate
examples: The vines intertwine around the garden trellis
Their lives would intertwine in unexpected ways

definitions: come between disputing people groups or events to prevent or alter a result
examples: The teacher had to intervene when students started fighting
The government may intervene if the strike continues

definitions: frighten or overawe someone especially to make them do what one wants
examples: The bully tried to intimidate younger students for their lunch money
Don't let the difficult exam questions intimidate you

definitions: arouse the curiosity or interest of someone by being unusual mysterious or fascinating
make secret plans to do something harmful or illegal especially with others
examples: The mysterious package on her desk intrigued her
His unusual accent and mannerisms intrigue everyone he meets
The courtiers would intrigue against each other for power
They intrigue to overthrow the current leadership

definitions: put oneself deliberately into a place or situation where one is unwelcome or uninvited
examples: Please don't intrude on their private conversation
Unwanted thoughts sometimes intrude during meditation

definitions: understand or work out something by instinct without conscious reasoning or evidence
examples: She could intuit his mood from his body language
Good teachers often intuit when students need extra help

definitions: make something legally or officially unacceptable void or without force
prove that an argument theory or claim is wrong or without foundation
examples: The court may invalidate the contract due to fraud
Forgetting to sign will invalidate your application form
New evidence could invalidate their scientific theory
One small error can invalidate the entire calculation

definitions: put something upside down or in the opposite position order or arrangement
examples: Invert the cake pan onto a serving plate
The pilot had to invert the aircraft during the stunt

definitions: send a bill for goods or services provided listing costs and payment terms
examples: The contractor will invoice us after completing the renovation
Please invoice the client for the consulting work performed

definitions: cite or appeal to someone or something as an authority for an action or in support
call on a deity or spirit in prayer as a witness or for inspiration
examples: The lawyer will invoke the Fifth Amendment during testimony
The president may invoke emergency powers during the crisis
The priest will invoke blessings upon the congregation
Ancient warriors would invoke their gods before battle

definitions: supply water to land or crops to help growth typically by channels pipes or streams
examples: Farmers irrigate their fields during the dry summer months
The new system will irrigate the entire vineyard automatically

definitions: make someone annoyed impatient or angry by continued unpleasant behavior
cause inflammation or other physical discomfort to a body part
examples: Loud music tends to irritate people trying to study
His constant complaining began to irritate his coworkers
The harsh soap may irritate your sensitive skin
Smoke from the fire will irritate your eyes and throat

definitions: feel an uncomfortable sensation on the skin that causes a desire to scratch
have a restless desire or longing to do something
examples: Mosquito bites always make my skin itch terribly
The wool sweater made her arms itch all day
The students itch to start their summer vacation
He was itching to tell someone the exciting news

definitions: perform or utter something repeatedly often with small variations or improvements each time
examples: The software developers iterate the design based on user feedback
Scientists iterate their experiments to verify the results

definitions: poke someone or something roughly or quickly with something sharp or pointed
examples: The nurse will jab the needle into your arm quickly
He tends to jab his finger at people when arguing

definitions: lift something heavy using a mechanical device designed for this purpose
raise or increase something suddenly and by a large amount
examples: You need to jack up the car to change the tire
Workers will jack the house to repair the foundation
The company plans to jack up prices before the holidays
They decided to jack their offer to secure the deal

definitions: cut or tear something to produce a rough sharp or irregular edge
examples: Be careful not to jag the fabric while cutting
The broken glass will jag your skin if touched

definitions: squeeze pack or wedge something or someone tightly into a space
become stuck or unable to move or work due to obstruction
play music informally with others especially improvising without preparation
examples: Don't jam too many clothes into the suitcase
Hundreds of fans tried to jam into the small venue
Paper scraps can jam the printer if not removed
Heavy traffic will jam the intersection during rush hour
The musicians love to jam together on weekends
Local bands often jam at the coffee shop

definitions: make or cause to make a harsh discordant ringing sound like metal objects striking together
examples: The keys jangle loudly in his pocket when he walks
Don't jangle those bells near the sleeping baby
